Welcome to c3py’s documentation!¶

Contents:

class c3py.Chart(name, local_jquery=None, local_requirejs=None, local_d3_js=None, local_c3_js=None, local_c3_css=None)¶

Create an instance of this class for each chart to be displayed. The various chart attributes and their methods can be used to customise the data represented, and the chart’s appearance.

Parameters:
  • name (string) – The name of the chart. This will be the id of the div that holds the chart. Therefore no two charts in the same document should have the same name.
  • local_jquery (string; default = None) – Path to a local version of jquery. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_requirejs (string; default = None) – Path to a local version of requirejs. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_d3_js (string; default = None) – Path to a local version of d3js. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_c3_js (string; default = None) – Path to a local version of c3js. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_c3_css (string; default = None) – Path to a local version of c3’s css. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
axes = <c3py.axes.Axes object>¶
data = <c3py.data.Data object>¶
get_html_string()¶

Returns the HTML string which will draw the chart.

In a Jupyter notebook, this would usually be used as the argument for IPython.display.HTML(), for the interactive chart to be displayed in the notebook.

That is, IPython.display.HTML(chart.get_html_string()).
